properties.name: ABC No Rio
properties.description: Posted by Milo156 Rivington Street New York, NYThe ABC No Rio Zine Library contains over seven thousand items. Our collection includes independent, underground and marginal publications on subjects such as music, culture, politics, personal experience and travel. We are most interested in zines addressing political and social issues. Our focus does not include poetry.

properties.description: Posted by MiloA (growing) collection of over 500 zines, comix, artist books and unique bookworks. Titles range from feminist, queer, and vegan to foozeball, poodles and absinthe. Toc Toc Cafe, 6091 Parc Avenue (corner Van Horne, bus #80 Parc). OPENING HOURS Wednesday - Sunday, 4 PM - midnight.

properties.name: Ché Café Zine Library at UCSD
properties.description: Posted by Milo9500 Gilman Dr. La Jolla, CAThe Che Cafe Zine Library is just beginning to grow. Currently there are only about 100 zines. The library contains independent, underground and some marginal publications on subjects such as politics, music, culture, personal experience and travel. The Zine library is "open" during any che event. If you\'d like to drop by and look at zines when there is no event going on, feel free to call us at (858)534-2311, and if someone\'s there, you may be able to stop by.

properties.name: Idle Kids Zine Library
properties.description: Posted by Milo3535 Cass Ave. Detroit, MIThe Zine Library is a collection of zines (small press, independent, mostly hand-made magazines) housed by Idle Kids Books & Records. It began with the donation of the zine library collection from the now-extinct VG Kids space. Since then, it has grown wildly from donations from personal collections and from magazines themselves. Along with our zine library and our for-sale zines, we also have a free-info shop set-up in our new space; with books and pamphlets, on a variety of topics.

properties.name: Kansas City Public Library Zine Collection
properties.description: Posted by Milo14 West 10th Street : Kansas City, MOThis collection includes zines, mini-comics, and mail art produced by local Kansas Citians. Zines (pronounced “zeens” as in the word magazine) are self-published works of art and writing where the author creates the content, layout, and has a large hand in the production of the final product. Mini-comics are similar to zines in that they are self-published comics produced and distributed by the artists. Mail art is a form of self-expression that takes place through mail correspondence where artists share collages, artwork, and writing with each other. Read more about zines at Wikipedia. This is an open collection that continues to grow as donations are acquired from local artists and zine collectors.

properties.name: King Richard (June, 2006)
properties.description: Posted by Milo At one point Richard Pryor was the king of comedy. Now he\'s pushing up daisies. Lat,Long: 43.06759,-87.90043

properties.name: Little Maga/Zine Collection at SFPL
properties.description: Posted by Milo100 Larkin Street, San Francisco, CAThe Little Maga/Zine Collection represents the intellectual activity of the people of San Francisco, from the twentieth century onward. An important tool for understanding the literary, social, political, and cultural experience of San Francisco, the Little Maga/Zine Collection tells the story of life in the cool grey City by the Bay.

properties.name: Madison Info Shop
properties.description: Posted by Milo 1019 Williamson Street, Madison, WIThe infoshop offers a diverse wealth of resources to the community including... * books * magazines and newspapers * zines and independent/diy press * videos and DVDs * topic files on a variety of subjects * pamphlets and factsheets Nearly all of these materials are available for check-out for long-term research. We also have a variety of of resources for community activists such as banners, signs, costumes and props for street theater, a button maker, media contact lists, and literature for distribution. Also, when you\'re here, check out the cool political buttons, bumper stickers, t-shirts and other items we offer for sale or donations.

properties.name: Papercut Zine Library
properties.description: Posted by Milo45 Mount Auburn Street, Cambridge, MAWe\'re a free lending library of zines and other independent media. We have zines in all sorts of categories: Political, Feminist, Environmentalist/Animals, Health/Sexuality, Erotica/Porn, Personal, Comics, Art/Film, Literature/Poetry, Queer/Trans, Race, Religion, Travel, Food/Cookbooks, Sports/Bikes, DIY/How-To, Foreign Language, Music, and Parenting/Educations. We\'re located in Cambridge, Massachusetts in Harvard Square - 45 Mt. Auburn St. Email us at papercut@riseup.net. 617-492-2606. Open daily. We\'re always taking donations of zines!

properties.name: Sweet Candy Zine Library and Distro
properties.description: Posted by Milo1508 S. 4th St. Philadelphia, PAThe Sweet Candy Zine Library is located in the Alternative Arts Center in South Philadelphia. You\'ll find us at 1508 S. 4th St. The library is a free space that is open to the public on select days so I would keep updated by checking out our calendar. You will find a relaxed setting with chairs, a couch, throw pillows to rest on if you\'d like to read on the floor and also complimentary treats & coffee/tea too! We currently have over 694 zine titles in stock, check our catalog for titles.

properties.name: The Queer Zine Archive Project
properties.description: Posted by Milo     The mission of the Queer Zine Archive Project (QZAP) is to establish a "living history" archive of past and present queer zines and to encourage current and emerging zine publishers to continue to create. In curating such a unique aspect of culture, we value a collectivist approach that respects the diversity of experiences that fall under the heading "queer." The primary function of QZAP is to provide a free on-line searchable database of the collection with links allowing users to download electronic copies of zines. By providing access to the historical canon of queer zines we hope to make them more accessible to diverse communities and reach wider audiences.

properties.name: Unite! (June, 2007)
properties.description: Posted by MiloThis well worn stencil has been on the corner in front of the Riverwest Co-op for a couple of years.

properties.name: West Coast Zine Collection at SDSU
properties.description: Posted by Milo5500 Campanile Drive, San Diego, CAThe West Coast Zine Archive\'s aim is to provide a protected space for Do-it-Yourself collections while advancing public access to these important works. This archive will protect and preserve tangible evidence of these unique literary creations to come. Zines in this collection will not circulate beyond the library, but Archive is open to all patrons of the library. The archive features zines related to gender and gender issues, music, art, and popular and alternative culture. This Archive focuses on publications West of the Mississippi and South of the U.S.-Mexico Border; but zines from other regions are also accepted and added to the Archive. We are requesting donations of single issues as well as large collections. Donations are tax-deductible and donor names will be credited in the Archive\'s inventory list. Allow someone 100 years from now to read what life was like for YOU and have your publication live on indefinitely. Have extra zines just collecting dust where few people can enjoy? Send us those too!

properties.name: Zine Archive Publishing Project (ZAPP)
properties.description: Posted by Milo The Zine Archive & Publishing Project exists to validate independent publications (extant and defunct, past and present), to promote the perpetuation of the art form, and to champion freedom of speech and creative cultural evolution. Located downstairs in the Hugo House basement ZAPP collects zines, comics, chapbooks, pamphlets, journals, gazettes, city papers, fan \'zines, art mags, monographs, short anthologies, personal transmissions, and other not-so-easily classified independent publications for preservation and display.

properties.name: Zinelibrary.net
properties.description: Posted by Milo4038 North Mississippi Ave, Portland, ORZinelibrary.net is an online archive of anti-capitalist, anti-authoritarian publications, saved in PDF format. PDFs are viewed using Adobe Reader, and are a free and universal format for read-only documents.
